options.B: the approach path will be steeper and threshold speed higher.
options.C: the landing distance required will be longer.

key_points: The strong tailwind will result in an increased actual Groundspeed (GS = TAS + tailwind), thus the aircraft will cover the same distance in a less flight time and the trip fuel consumed will be also less, in comparison with the planned trip fuel
The Landing Mass is equal to the Actual Take-off Mass minus the Trip Fuel
Since, the actual trip fuel consumption reduces, the actual Landing Mass will be greater than the planned on arrival at destination
learning.explanation: The strong tailwind will result in an increased actual Groundspeed (GS = TAS + tailwind), thus the aircraft will cover the same distance in a less flight time and the trip fuel consumed will be also less, in comparison with the planned trip fuel. The Landing Mass is equal to the Actual Take-off Mass minus the Trip Fuel. Since, the actual trip fuel consumption reduces, the actual Landing Mass will be greater than the planned on arrival at destination. Also, the given straight in approach and immediate landing clearance will not allow any additional fuel consumption. Therefore, the higher actual Landing Mass than planned will result in an increased stalling speed and threshold speed, VREF, thus the landing distance required will increase considerably.

content.question: What is the result if the Center of Gravity (CG) of an aircraft is located beyond its forward CG limit?

key_points: The stick force required to maintain level flight with a forward CG is considerably more than it is with a neutral CG, because the aeroplane is nose-heavy
Forward CG means that we have a longer arm between CG and CP where lift acts
However, the distance between CG and the tail is not increased by the same proportion
learning.explanation: The stick force required to maintain level flight with a forward CG is considerably more than it is with a neutral CG, because the aeroplane is nose-heavy. Forward CG means that we have a longer arm between CG and CP where lift acts. However, the distance between CG and the tail is not increased by the same proportion. Therefore tailplane needs to produce more downforce LT (drag) to balance. This means that when the centre of gravity is moved beyond its forward limit, drag is increased. This drag increase causes the range of the aircraft to decrease. Range ⇒ the maximum distance an aircraft can travel between take-off and landing under its own power while carrying a specific payload. Endurance ⇒ the maximum time an aircraft can remain airborne on a single load of fuel.

learning.explanation: The total mass of the aircraft can be said to act through one point, called the Centre of Gravity (CG) and the total lift acts through the Centre of Pressure (CP). The relative positions of the CG and CP affect the longitudinal stability of the aircraft. In practice, the CG is usually forward of the CP, thus, the more forward the CG, the more stable the aircraft in pitch, but the more downforce at the elevator is required to change the pitch attitude. Some stability in pitch is desirable, but not too much, because the extra down force on the elevator effectively adds to the aircraft weight and requires the lift to be increased to counter it. More lift means more drag created by the trim (trim drag) and more drag means higher fuel consumption. In summary, the effects of a forward CG position are the following: Decreases the Rate of Climb and the Climb gradient Increases TORR, TODR, ASDR, thus MTOM must be decreased The stick forces required will be more Rotation will be more difficult Stall speed increases, thus ceiling decreases Makes flare more difficult during landing, thus increasing LDR and decreasing MLM Due to the increased fuel consumption, the fuel mileage (nautical miles covered per kg of fuel mass) decrease

content.question: Some aircraft are equipped with fuel trim tanks located in the aeroplane’s fin or horizontal stabiliser to actively manage CG position. Which of the following is an advantage of having a trim tank in the horizontal stabiliser?

options.C: It allows the crew to keep the CG at an aft position.
options.D: It increases the efficiency of the elevator during slow flight.

key_points: The fuel tanks will generally be located in the wings (outer and inner) and in a central position in the fuselage
But, they may also be found in the fin and the horizontal stabiliser
The Centre of Gravity (CG) position does change as fuel is burnt off, but within defined limits
learning.explanation: The fuel tanks will generally be located in the wings (outer and inner) and in a central position in the fuselage. But, they may also be found in the fin and the horizontal stabiliser. The Centre of Gravity (CG) position does change as fuel is burnt off, but within defined limits. If it is burnt from a tank aft of the aircraft's CG, then the CG will move forward. Conversely, if the fuel is burnt from a tank positioned forward of the CG, then it will move aft. Over the years, fuel tanks in the tail fin and horizontal stabiliser, called as "trim tanks", have been employed by different manufacturers for two main reasons: To provide extra fuel capacity. To maintain the aircraft CG position at the optimum (aft) position for minimum drag, improved manoeuvrability and, as a consequence, for maximum fuel economy, as less downforce on the horizontal stabiliser is required. The fuel in these tanks may automatically drain as fuel is used from the centre and wing tanks or may be actively controlled by the crew through transfer systems.

learning.explanation: When the aircraft's center of gravity is at a forward position, several interconnected effects come into play. First, a forward centre of gravity leads to an increase in drag, subsequently causing an increased fuel consumption, while both the aircraft's range and endurance experience a reduction. In order to counteract the resultant downward pitch of the aircraft's nose, the tailplane must generate a compensatory downward force, akin to the mechanism of a seesaw. This corrective force induces an upward movement of the elevators, which unfortunately amplifies drag, thereby intensifying fuel consumption and curtailing the aircraft's range and endurance. This elevation in downward force exerted by the tailplane can be likened to an increase in overall weight. Consequently, the stall speed of the aircraft also increases. Take-off and landing speeds experience an increase.

learning.explanation: Stall speeds are determined with the least favourible CG position. For an aircraft, this is the most forward point because then the main wing will be producing the most lift. With the cg furthest ahead of the centre of pressure, the horizontal stabilizer will be producing a downwards force, which the main wings will have to compensate for by producing more lift. The main wings will therefore have to be at a higher angle of attack and therefore be closer to the stall. Hence the stall will occur at higher speeds with a forward CG then with a rearward CG. Minimum control speeds are also determined with the least favourible conditions. When considering an engine failure, we know that the aircraft will rotate around its CG, but the distance of the moment doesn’t change when it moves fore or aft, the engines moment would only change when we move it along the lateral axis of the aircraft. However, the position of the CG will influence the rudder arm, and hence the rudder moment. content.question: What will be the effect on the longitudinal static stability, if the Centre of Gravity (CG) is located behind the aft CG limit?

options.A: Longitudinal stability is NOT related to the position of the CG.
options.C: There is a significant increase in stability.

key_points: The relative positions of the Centre of Gravity (CG) and Centre of Pressure (CP) affect the longitudinal stability of the aircraft
Most transport aircraft will usually have their aft CG limit just forward of the CP, because that provides to an aircraft pitch stability
If the CP is aft of the CG, the increased lift vector will tip the aircraft nose down, which is a stable result as it tends to restore the original pitch attitude
learning.explanation: The relative positions of the Centre of Gravity (CG) and Centre of Pressure (CP) affect the longitudinal stability of the aircraft. Most transport aircraft will usually have their aft CG limit just forward of the CP, because that provides to an aircraft pitch stability. If the CP is aft of the CG, the increased lift vector will tip the aircraft nose down, which is a stable result as it tends to restore the original pitch attitude. In this case, the aircraft has positive longitudinal static stability. If the CG is aft of the CP, thus positioned behind the aft limit, the increased lift will tip the aircraft nose up, leading to higher angles of attack and even more lift until the aircraft stalls. This is an unstable result, a negative longitudinal static stability, where: The control forces will be light. The aircraft will be excessively controllable, leading to a possible over rotation on take-off and a possible tail scrape and during landing over pitching may occur during the flare. Insufficient forward longitudinal control will be available to keep the aircraft level in straight flight. If the CG is too far aft, the moment arm between it and the CP diminishes, reducing the inherent stability of the airplane beyond acceptable limits and in the extreme going negative and rendering the airplane longitudinally unstable. Generally, the less stable the aircraft, the more controllable and vice versa.

learning.explanation: The performance limited landing mass (PLLM) is the mass subject to the landing aerodrome limitations also taking the current metrological conditions into account. This limit is not a set figure and needs to be calculated for each sector. If the PLLM is exceeded the aircraft may overrun the landing distance available, tyre temperature limits could be exceeded, a go-around might not be achievable and there is a risk of structural fatigue. The regulated landing mass (RLM) is the is the lowest of the performance limited landing mass and maximum structural limited landing mass. The actual landing mass must not exceed this limit. The maximum structural landing mass (MSLM) is the maximum permissible total aeroplane mass on landing in normal circumstances and given the most favourable conditions anywhere in the world. It is a set structural limitation and does not change for a particular aircraft. If the MSLM is exceeded structural damage can occur to the aircraft.

content.question: The allowable take-off mass is…

options.A: The lowest of PLTOM and MSTOM.
options.B: The lowest of the regulated TOM and PLTOM plus trip fuel.
options.C: The greater of PLTOM and MSTOM.
options.D: The greater of the regulated TOM and PLTOM plus trip fuel.

key_points: Learning Objectives 031
learning.explanation: Learning Objectives 031.02.03.01.01: Calculate the maximum mass for take-off (regulated take-off mass) given mass-and-load components and structural/ performance limits. When we do our take-off performance calculations for a specific runway in specific conditions, the main factor (and often the figure we are trying to find) is our maximum take-off mass (MTOM). In actual fact, there are many different MTOMs, and we have to find the most limiting, which will be the lowest of the set. None of the structural or performance limitations are permitted to be exceeded. In order to ensure the aircraft remains within all of the limitations, a calculation is required to check which is the most restrictive on that particular flight. The single most restrictive limitation is called the allowed takeoff mass (ATOM) and is the lowest of performance limited takeoff mas (PLTOM) and maximum structural take-off mass (MSTOM). The most limiting (smallest value) of these will be the one where our aircraft will struggle most for performance.

content.question: What is the effect of a forward CG in front of the forward limit?

options.C: Increased efficiency and reduced maximum ceiling.
options.D: Decreased efficiency and increased maximum ceiling.

key_points: The relationship between your aircraft's performance and CG location is simple: by moving your CG forward and aft, you change the amount of tail down force and lift you need for stable flight
When you create more lift, you create more induced drag, and your performance goes down
The aircraft cruises slower with a forward CG location because of increased drag
learning.explanation: The relationship between your aircraft's performance and CG location is simple: by moving your CG forward and aft, you change the amount of tail down force and lift you need for stable flight. When you create more lift, you create more induced drag, and your performance goes down. The aircraft cruises slower with a forward CG location because of increased drag. The drag is increased because a higher AoA and much downward deflection of the stabilizer are required to support the aircraft and overcome the nose-down pitching tendency. This pitch down moment has to be corrected by an up deflection of the elevator to keep straight and level flight. This increases the aircraft’s weight by adding a high downward force. Considering this information, the effect of a forward CG in front of the forward limit is "Reduced efficiency and maximum ceiling".

content.question: The CG of an aircraft is on the forward limit. Which of the following is a probable outcome?

options.A: There may not be enough aft stick force, resulting in a tail strike.
options.C: There may not be enough aft stick force, resulting in a nose wheel landing.
options.D: Deep stall caused by insufficient tail lift.

key_points: CENTER OF GRAVITY (CG) The total mass of the aircraft can be said to act through one point, called the Centre of Gravity (CG)
To ensure the aircraft is safe to fly, the center of gravity must fall within specified limits established by the aircraft manufacturer (between the front and the rear CG limit)
Proper CG location is crucial for maintaining the aircraft's stability and controllability
learning.explanation: CENTER OF GRAVITY (CG) The total mass of the aircraft can be said to act through one point, called the Centre of Gravity (CG). To ensure the aircraft is safe to fly, the center of gravity must fall within specified limits established by the aircraft manufacturer (between the front and the rear CG limit). Proper CG location is crucial for maintaining the aircraft's stability and controllability. Beginning from the middle of the fuselage: As the CG shifts towards the aircraft's nose, stability increases while maneuverability decreases. As the CG moves towards the tail, maneuverability improves, but stability diminishes. A more stable aircraft is less controllable and vice versa. Excessive stability leads to higher control stick forces, making it more challenging for the pilot to manage. On the other hand, excessive maneuverability results in instability and difficulty in controlling the aircraft. When the CG is at the forward limit, the aircraft's nose may become too heavy making it difficult to raise the nose during landing, leading to a higher likelihood of landing on the nose wheel rather than the main wheels.

CG towards the aft limit decreases longitudinal static stability and reduces pitch control forces. When the Center of gravity is outside the forward limit, this gives us a pitch down moment, this pitch down moment has to be corrected by an up deflection of elevator to keep straight and level flight (by pulling the control column – control column aft). If the CG is located ahead of the forward limit, the aircraft's nose will be heavy, and there may not be sufficient aft pitch control available to keep the aircraft level. This can lead to difficulty in raising the nose during take-off and flare before landing, which can result in a longer take-off or landing roll, and may also make the aircraft more difficult to control in flight.

content.question: If other factors are unchanged, the fuel mileage (nautical miles per kg) is...

options.A: lower with a forward centre of gravity position
options.B: independent from the centre of gravity position
options.C: lower with an aft centre of gravity position
options.D: higher with a forward centre of gravity position

key_points: The total mass of the aircraft can be said to act through one point, called the Centre of Gravity (CG) and the total lift acts through the Centre of Pressure (CP)
The position of the CP changes with speed and as alpha changes, whilst the position of CG changes as load and fuel change
When this happens, new balancing forces and trim changes will be needed
learning.explanation: The total mass of the aircraft can be said to act through one point, called the Centre of Gravity (CG) and the total lift acts through the Centre of Pressure (CP). The position of the CP changes with speed and as alpha changes, whilst the position of CG changes as load and fuel change. When this happens, new balancing forces and trim changes will be needed. The relative positions of the CG and CP affect the longitudinal stability of the aircraft. In practice, the CG is usually forward of the CP, thus, the more forward the CG, the more stable the aircraft in pitch. Some stability in pitch is desirable, but not too much, because the extra down force on the elevator effectively adds to the aircraft weight and requires the lift to be increased to counter it. More lift means more drag created by the trim (trim drag) and more drag means higher fuel consumption. Aircraft manufacturers determine a safe range for the CG. The aft limit is usually just in front of the Centre of Pressure, but it provides less stability than that provided by the forward limit, but a smaller balancing tail moment will be required. In summary, the effects of a forward CG position are the following: Decreases the Rate of Climb and the Climb gradient Increases TORR, TODR, ASDR, thus MTOM must be decreased The stick forces required will be more Rotation will be more difficult Stall speed increases, thus ceiling decreases Makes flare more difficult during landing, thus increasing LDR and decreasing MLM Due to the increased fuel consumption, the fuel mileage (nautical miles covered per kg of fuel mass) decrease

content.question: What are the possible consequences when loading an aircraft incorrectly so that its CG is positioned behind the aft limit?

options.A: There may be insufficient forward pitch control available to keep the aircraft level in straight flight.
options.B: There may be insufficient aft pitch control available to keep the aircraft level in straight flight.
options.C: The aircraft will be extremely stable.
options.D: There may be an inability to flare the aircraft on landing.

key_points: The relative positions of the Centre of Gravity (CG) and Centre of Pressure (CP) affect the longitudinal stability of the aircraft
Most transport aircraft will usually have their aft CG limit just forward of the CP, because that provides to an aircraft pitch stability
If the CP is aft of the CG, the increased lift vector will tip the aircraft nose down, which is a stable result as it tends to restore the original pitch attitude
learning.explanation: The relative positions of the Centre of Gravity (CG) and Centre of Pressure (CP) affect the longitudinal stability of the aircraft. Most transport aircraft will usually have their aft CG limit just forward of the CP, because that provides to an aircraft pitch stability. If the CP is aft of the CG, the increased lift vector will tip the aircraft nose down, which is a stable result as it tends to restore the original pitch attitude. In this case, the aircraft has positive longitudinal static stability. If the CG is aft of the CP, thus positioned behind the aft limit, the increased lift will tip the aircraft nose up, leading to higher angles of attack and even more lift until the aircraft stalls. This is an unstable result, a negative longitudinal static stability, where: The control forces will be light. The aircraft will be excessively manoeuvrable, leading to a possible over rotation on take-off and a possible tail scrape and during landing over pitching may occur during the flare. Insufficient forward pitch control will be available to keep the aircraft level in straight flight.

learning.explanation: The relative positions of the Centre of Gravity (CG) and Centre of Pressure (CP) affect the longitudinal stability of the aircraft. Most transport aircraft will usually have their aft CG limit just forward of the CP, because that provides to an aircraft pitch stability. If the CP is aft of the CG, the increased lift vector will tip the aircraft nose down, which is a stable result as it tends to restore the original pitch attitude. In this case, the aircraft has positive longitudinal static stability. If the CG is aft of the CP, thus positioned behind the aft limit, the increased lift will tip the aircraft nose up, leading to higher angles of attack and even more lift until the aircraft stalls. This is an unstable result, a negative longitudinal static stability, where: The control forces will be light. The aircraft will be excessively controllable, leading to a possible over rotation on take-off and a possible tail scrape and during landing over pitching may occur during the flare. Insufficient forward longitudinal control will be available to keep the aircraft level in straight flight. If the CG is too far aft, the moment arm between it and the CP diminishes, reducing the inherent stability of the airplane beyond acceptable limits and in the extreme going negative and rendering the airplane longitudinally unstable. Generally, the less stable the aircraft, the more controllable and vice versa.

learning.explanation: The total mass of the aircraft can be said to act through one point, called the Centre of Gravity (CG) and the total lift acts through the Centre of Pressure (CP). The position of the CP changes with speed and as alpha changes, whilst the position of CG changes as load and fuel change. When this happens, new balancing forces and trim changes will be needed. The relative positions of the CG and CP affect the longitudinal stability of the aircraft. In practice, the CG is usually forward of the CP, thus, the more forward the CG, the more stable the aircraft in pitch. Some stability in pitch is desirable, but not too much, because the extra down force on the elevator effectively adds to the aircraft weight and requires the lift to be increased to counter it. More lift means more drag created by the trim (trim drag) and more drag means higher fuel consumption. Aircraft manufacturers determine a safe range for the CG. The aft limit is usually just in front of the Centre of Pressure, but it provides less stability than that provided by the forward limit, but a smaller balancing tail moment will be required. In summary, the effects of a forward CG position are the following: Decreases the Rate of Climb and the Climb gradient Increases TORR, TODR, ASDR, thus MTOM must be decreased The stick forces required will be more Rotation will be more difficult Stall speed increases, thus ceiling decreases Makes flare more difficult during landing, thus increasing LDR and decreasing MLM Due to the increased fuel consumption, the fuel mileage (nautical miles covered per kg of fuel mass) decrease

options.B: There may be insufficient aft pitch control available to keep the aircraft level in straight flight.

key_points: The relative positions of the Centre of Gravity (CG) and Centre of Pressure (CP) affect the longitudinal stability of the aircraft
Most transport aircraft will usually have their aft CG limit just forward of the CP, because that provides to an aircraft pitch stability
If the CP is aft of the CG, the increased lift vector will tip the aircraft nose down, which is a stable result as it tends to restore the original pitch attitude
learning.explanation: The relative positions of the Centre of Gravity (CG) and Centre of Pressure (CP) affect the longitudinal stability of the aircraft. Most transport aircraft will usually have their aft CG limit just forward of the CP, because that provides to an aircraft pitch stability. If the CP is aft of the CG, the increased lift vector will tip the aircraft nose down, which is a stable result as it tends to restore the original pitch attitude. In this case, the aircraft has positive longitudinal static stability. If the CG is aft of the CP, thus positioned behind the aft limit, the increased lift will tip the aircraft nose up, leading to higher angles of attack and even more lift until the aircraft stalls. This is an unstable result, a negative longitudinal static stability, where: The control forces will be light. The aircraft will be excessively manoeuvrable, leading to a possible over rotation on take-off and a possible tail scrape and during landing over pitching may occur during the flare. Insufficient forward pitch control will be available to keep the aircraft level in straight flight.

content.question: Which equation represents a convertion of 1 US gallon AVGAS into lbs?

The IG is larger than the USG: 1 IG = 1
2 USG 1 USG = 0

The IG is larger than the USG: 1 IG = 1.2 USG 1 USG = 0.83 IG 1 IG = 4.545 lt 1 USG = 3.785 lt A relationship exists between litres and kilograms and also between Imperial gallons and libres: One litre of water weighs one kilogram. One IG of water weighs ten libres. To convert fuel volumes into fuel masses, we need to know that fuel is lighter than water. A volume of AVGAS weighs approximately 73% of the equivalent volume of water, which means that its Specific Gravity (SG) is approximately 0.73. This means that an IG of AVGAS weighs: 10 x 0.73 lb = 7.3 lb. Thus, 1 USG will weigh: 7.3 lb x 0.83 IG = 6 lb.

content.question: Under which circumstances is zero fuel mass at its maximum?

key_points: Maximum Zero Fuel Mass (MZFM) is the maximum permissible mass of an aeroplane with no usable fuel
The MZFM is a structural limit based on the bending moments of the wing root

Due to the necessity of using the mass of fuel in the aircraft’s wing tanks to balance the internal load, there is a restriction on the amount of weight that can be placed in the fuselage before fuel must be added to the wing tanks
learning.explanation: Maximum Zero Fuel Mass (MZFM) is the maximum permissible mass of an aeroplane with no usable fuel. The MZFM is a structural limit based on the bending moments of the wing root. Due to the necessity of using the mass of fuel in the aircraft’s wing tanks to balance the internal load, there is a restriction on the amount of weight that can be placed in the fuselage before fuel must be added to the wing tanks. Exceeding the MZFM limit can result in significant structural damage to the aircraft. The greatest stress on the wing roots happens when the wing fuel tanks are empty. To prevent the wings from permanently bending upward as fuel is used, manufacturers impose a maximum zero fuel mass on the structure. Since the stress during flight is at its greatest when the wing fuel tanks are empty, MZFM is determined during approach for landing. Fuel jettison is a procedure used to quickly reduce the weight of an aircraft by releasing fuel into the atmosphere. This procedure is typically performed in emergency situations when an aircraft needs to land but is too heavy to do so safely. Note: The option 'Immediately after fuel jettison (IFJ)' is not considered the correct option, because fuel jettison does not necessarily mean getting rid of all the fuel.

Given the following information for an aircraft, what is its maximum Traffic Load available?
Dry Operating Mass: 3000 kg
Maximum Take-off, Landing, and Zero-fuel Mass: 5200 kg

key_points: Since all structural limits are identical and all of them contain at least the DOM, the most limiting factor is the MTOM, because, in addition to the DOM, it contains also the greatest amount of fuel, the Take-off fuel (in comparison with the landing fuel), which if subtracted will give the maximum available Traffic Load
Thus, the Maximum available TL will be: MTOM - DOM - Take-off fuel = MTOM - DOM - (Ramp fuel - Taxi fuel) = 5200 kg - 3000 kg - (650 kg - 50 kg) = 1600 kg

Alternatively, using a tabular format, find the maximum TL in terms of each structural limit and keep the lowest one: MTOM: 5200 kg MZFM: 5200 kg MLM: 5200 kg - DOM 3000 kg 3000 kg 3000 kg - FUEL T/O fuel: 650 - 50 = 600 kg - Landing fuel: less than 600 kg = TL 1600 kg 2200 kg More than 1600 kg Thus, the lowest TL, 1600 kg, in terms of MTOM, is the Maximum available TL

Thus, the Maximum available TL will be: MTOM - DOM - Take-off fuel = MTOM - DOM - (Ramp fuel - Taxi fuel) = 5200 kg - 3000 kg - (650 kg - 50 kg) = 1600 kg. Given the following information, what is the Underload/Overload?
Allowed Take-off Mass: 4 300 kg
Operating Mass: 3 296 kg
Total Fuel Mass: 650 kg
Mass of the crew and their baggage: 187 kg
Traffic Load: 1 014 kg

key_points: Traffic Load (TL) is is the total mass of passengers, baggage and cargo, including any ’non-revenue’ load
Dry Operating Mass (DOM) is the total mass of the aeroplane ready for a specific type of operation excluding usable fuel and traffic load
The mass includes items such as crew and crew baggage, catering and removable passenger service equipment, potable water and lavatory chemicals, food and beverages
learning.explanation: Traffic Load (TL) is is the total mass of passengers, baggage and cargo, including any ’non-revenue’ load. Dry Operating Mass (DOM) is the total mass of the aeroplane ready for a specific type of operation excluding usable fuel and traffic load. The mass includes items such as crew and crew baggage, catering and removable passenger service equipment, potable water and lavatory chemicals, food and beverages. Operating Mass (OM) is the DOM plus fuel, but without traffic load. For this question we will only consider the take-off situation (ignoring the landing and the zero-fuel situation, since the given data do not permit so) subtracting from the Allowed Take-off mass structural limit, the OM and the Traffic load to figure out if the aircraft is overloaded or underloaded: Allowed TOM - OM - Traffic Load = 4 300 kg - 3 296 kg - 1 014 kg = - 10 kg. The "-" sign indicates that it is overloaded by 10 kg. NOTE: Be careful to avoid any double mass calculations, due to the fact that some masses are already included in other masses, e.g. fuel mass is included in OM, crew and crew baggage mass is included in DOM, DOM is included in OM and so on.

content.question: What is the minimum width of a clearway?

key_points: The clearway is described in EU-OPS, as a defined rectangular area on the ground or water under the control of the appropriate authority, selected or prepared as a suitable area over which an aeroplane may take a portion of its initial climb to a specified height
The clearway may be load bearing or not
The clearway is expressed in terms of a clearway plane with a minimum width of 500 feet (or 152 metres), extending from the end of the runway with an upward slope not exceeding 1
learning.explanation: The clearway is described in EU-OPS, as a defined rectangular area on the ground or water under the control of the appropriate authority, selected or prepared as a suitable area over which an aeroplane may take a portion of its initial climb to a specified height. The clearway may be load bearing or not. The clearway is expressed in terms of a clearway plane with a minimum width of 500 feet (or 152 metres), extending from the end of the runway with an upward slope not exceeding 1.25%, above which no object or terrain protrudes. However, threshold lights may protrude above the plane, if their height above the end of the runway is 0.66 metres (or 26 inches) or less and if they are located to each side of the runway. Also, the clearway may not be greater than 50% of the TORA and should extend at least 75 metres either side of the centre line. The TORA (Take-Off Run Available) plus the clearway make the TODA (Take-Off Distance Available).

key_points: The total aircraft mass at landing (landing mass) is the take-off mass reduced by all fuel used during the particular flight

In other words, LM is the zero fuel mass (ZFM) plus all fuel that should still be onboard. In this case, the fuel at landing will equal to the fuel loading minus fuel allowance for start, taxi and run up, minus estimated fuel burn-off. Fuel loading (lb) = 85 US Gal x 6 lb/US gal = 510 lb Fuel allowance for start, taxi and run up (lb) = 4 US gal x 6 lb/US gal = 24 lb Estimated fuel burn-off (lb) = 60 US gal x 6 lb/US gal = 360 lb Fuel at landing (lb) = 510 lb - 24 lb - 360 lb = 126 lb Landing Mass (LM) = BEM + Pilot and front passenger + Passengers + Baggage Zone 1 + Baggage Zone 4 + Fuel at landing Landing Mass (LM) = 3 210 lb + 380 lb + 330 lb + 100 lb + 100 lb + 126 lb = 4 246 lb

learning.explanation: Dry Operating Mass (DOM) is the sum of the Basic Empty Mass (BEM) and the Variable Load (crew, crew baggage, food, beverages, water etc.), excluding both usable fuel and payload. Traffic Load (TL) is the total mass of passengers, baggage, cargo (or freight), including any non-revenue load. Traffic Load plus Dry Operating Mass (DOM) is equal to the aircraft's Zero Fuel Mass (ZFM). Take-off Mass (TOM) is the mass of the aeroplane at the start of the take-off run. Given the following information, what will be the expected Landing Mass at the destination?
Maximum structural take-off mass: 8 600 kg
Maximum structural landing mass: 8 600 kg

Contingency fuel: 110 kg
Alternate fuel: 600 kg
Final Reserve Fuel: 130 kg
Trip Fuel: 970 kg

key_points: Landing Mass is the mass of the aircraft as it crosses the threshold on landing

Take-off Mass is equal to the Zero Fuel Mass plus the Take-off fuel
learning.explanation: Landing Mass is the mass of the aircraft as it crosses the threshold on landing. The expected Landing Mass is equal to the Take-off Mass minus the Trip fuel. Take-off Mass is equal to the Zero Fuel Mass plus the Take-off fuel. Take-off fuel is equal to: Trip Fuel + Contingency fuel + Alternate fuel + Final Reserve Fuel = 970 + 110 kg + 600 kg + 130 kg = 1 810 kg. So, the Take-off Mass is: ZFM + T/O Fuel = 6 500 kg + 1 810 kg = 8 310 kg. Therefore, the expected Landing Mass will be: Take-off Mass - Trip fuel = 8 310 kg - 970 kg = 7 340 kg, which is less than the Maximum Structural Landing Mass (8 600 kg).

content.question:
Given the following information, what is the Underload/Overload?
Allowed Take-off Mass: 4300 kg
Operating Mass: 3253 kg
Total fuel Mass: 650 kg
Mass of the crew and their baggage: 185 kg
Traffic Load: 1015 kg

key_points: Traffic Load (TL) is is the total mass of passengers, baggage and cargo, including any ’non-revenue’ load
Dry Operating Mass (DOM) is the total mass of the aeroplane ready for a specific type of operation excluding usable fuel and traffic load
The mass includes items such as crew and crew baggage, catering and removable passenger service equipment, potable water and lavatory chemicals, food and beverages
learning.explanation: Traffic Load (TL) is is the total mass of passengers, baggage and cargo, including any ’non-revenue’ load. Dry Operating Mass (DOM) is the total mass of the aeroplane ready for a specific type of operation excluding usable fuel and traffic load. The mass includes items such as crew and crew baggage, catering and removable passenger service equipment, potable water and lavatory chemicals, food and beverages. Operating Mass (OM) is the DOM plus fuel, but without traffic load. For this question we will only consider the take-off situation (ignoring the landing and the zero-fuel situation, since the given data do not permit so) subtracting from the Allowed Take-off mass structural limit the OM and the Traffic load to figure out if the aircraft is overloaded or underloaded: Allowed TOM - OM - Traffic Load = 4300 - 3253 - 1015 = + 32 kg. The "+" sign indicates that it is underloaded by 32 kg. NOTE: Be careful to avoid any double mass calculations, due to the fact that some masses are already included in other masses, e.g. fuel mass is included in OM, crew and crew baggage mass is included in DOM, DOM is included in OM and so on.

content.question:
The following data is extracted from an aeroplane loading manifest:
Take-off Mass (Performance Limited): 93 500 kg
Expected Landing Mass at destination: 81 700 kg
Maximum Certificated Landing Mass: 86 300 kg
Take-off Fuel on board: 16 500 kg
During the flight a diversion is made to an en-route alternate which is not performance limited for landing. Fuel remaining at landing is 10 300 kg. The Landing Mass…

options.A: is 83 200 kg which is in excess of the regulated Landing Mass and could result in overrunning the runway.
options.B: is 87 300 kg which is acceptable in this case because this is a diversion and not a normal scheduled landing.
options.C: is 87 300 kg and excess structural stress could result.
options.D: must be reduced to 81 700 kg in order to avoid a high speed approach.

key_points: The Actual Landing Mass at the alternate is: Take-off Mass - Trip fuel = Take-off Mass - (Take-off fuel on board - Landing Fuel) = 93 500 kg - (16 500 kg - 10 300 kg) = 87 300 kg
Alternatively, Actual LM = Zero Fuel Mass + Landing Fuel = (Take-off mass - Take-off fuel on board) + Landing fuel = (93 500 kg - 16 500 kg) + 10 300 kg = 87 300 kg
But, the Actual Landing Mass, 87 300 kg, will result to an excess structural stress, because it is greater than the Maximum Certificated Landing Mass structural limit, 86 300 kg
learning.explanation: The Actual Landing Mass at the alternate is: Take-off Mass - Trip fuel = Take-off Mass - (Take-off fuel on board - Landing Fuel) = 93 500 kg - (16 500 kg - 10 300 kg) = 87 300 kg. Alternatively, Actual LM = Zero Fuel Mass + Landing Fuel = (Take-off mass - Take-off fuel on board) + Landing fuel = (93 500 kg - 16 500 kg) + 10 300 kg = 87 300 kg. But, the Actual Landing Mass, 87 300 kg, will result to an excess structural stress, because it is greater than the Maximum Certificated Landing Mass structural limit, 86 300 kg.

You are about to depart for a Commercial Air Transport flight from Athens to Paris and then another flight back to Athens. For tankering purposes, you do not want to refuel in Paris, so will want to land there with 8 300 kg, as this is the Block Fuel for the return sector.
What is the minimum Block Fuel that should be onboard for the first flight from Athens?

key_points: We assume that the trip from Athens to Paris will go as planned, so no contingency, alternate, final reserve and additional fuel amount will be consumed and that all the trip fuel amount, 7 054 kg, will be consumed
According to the question, we will need an extra amount of fuel, 8 300 kg, so as to ensure that this amount will be on board when landing in Paris

learning.explanation: We assume that the trip from Athens to Paris will go as planned, so no contingency, alternate, final reserve and additional fuel amount will be consumed and that all the trip fuel amount, 7 054 kg, will be consumed. According to the question, we will need an extra amount of fuel, 8 300 kg, so as to ensure that this amount will be on board when landing in Paris. Additionally, taxi fuel, 180 kg, is required. So, adding the above fuel amounts, we get the Minimum Block Fuel: 7 054 kg + 8 300 kg + 180 kg = 15 534 kg, which is less than 22 000 kg, so we are within limits in terms of tank capacity. Also, check if with the above Minimum Block Fuel, 15534 kg, any maximum fuel load than can be loaded for both take-off and landing situations is exceeded, by subtracting the Dry Operating Mass and the Traffic Load from the two allowed structural limits given: Take-off: 69 002 kg - 42 123 kg - 10 489 kg = 16 390 kg (more than 15 534 kg, so we are within limits). content.question: In a turn flight, which scenario will cause the most bending moment at the wing root?

key_points: Maximum Zero Fuel Mass (MZFM) is the maximum permissible mass of an aeroplane with no usable fuel
The MZFM is a structural limit based on the bending moments of the wing root
All extra weight above the MZFM must comprise fuel only
learning.explanation: Maximum Zero Fuel Mass (MZFM) is the maximum permissible mass of an aeroplane with no usable fuel. The MZFM is a structural limit based on the bending moments of the wing root. All extra weight above the MZFM must comprise fuel only. The added fuel, which is invariably carried in the wing increases its stiffness and reduces its bending and torsion (twisting). Fuel being stored in the wings is a useful feature, as the weight of the fuel counteracts the lift generated and gives relief to the roots of the cantilever wing. However, with no fuel, the wings are light, and the fuselage is heavy, which causes a large moment at the root of the wing. Therefore, the maximum zero-fuel weight implies a protection to the wing root against being overstressed. As long as it is not exceeded, lack of large amounts of fuel in the wings will not cause failure at the wing roots because of bending.

content.question: What is the result if the Center of Gravity (CG) of an aircraft is located beyond its forward CG limit?

key_points: The stick force required to maintain level flight with a forward CG is considerably more than it is with a neutral CG, because the aeroplane is nose-heavy
Forward CG means that we have a longer arm between CG and CP where lift acts
However, the distance between CG and the tail is not increased by the same proportion
learning.explanation: The stick force required to maintain level flight with a forward CG is considerably more than it is with a neutral CG, because the aeroplane is nose-heavy. Forward CG means that we have a longer arm between CG and CP where lift acts. However, the distance between CG and the tail is not increased by the same proportion. Therefore tailplane needs to produce more downforce LT (drag) to balance. This means that when the centre of gravity is moved beyond its forward limit, drag is increased. This drag increase causes the range of the aircraft to decrease. Range ⇒ the maximum distance an aircraft can travel between take-off and landing under its own power while carrying a specific payload. Endurance ⇒ the maximum time an aircraft can remain airborne on a single load of fuel.

key_points: The relative positions of the Centre of Gravity (CG) and Centre of Pressure (CP) affect the longitudinal stability of the aircraft

learning.explanation: The relative positions of the Centre of Gravity (CG) and Centre of Pressure (CP) affect the longitudinal stability of the aircraft. Most transport aircraft will usually have their aft CG limit just forward of the CP, because that provides to an aircraft pitch stability. If the CP is aft of the CG, the increased lift vector will tip the aircraft nose down, which is a stable result as it tends to restore the original pitch attitude. In this case, the aircraft has positive longitudinal static stability. If the CG is aft of the CP, thus positioned behind the aft limit, the increased lift will tip the aircraft nose up, leading to higher angles of attack and even more lift until the aircraft stalls. This is an unstable result, a negative longitudinal static stability, where: The control forces will be light. The aircraft will be excessively controllable, leading to a possible over rotation on take-off and a possible tail scrape and during landing over pitching may occur during the flare. Insufficient forward longitudinal control will be available to keep the aircraft level in straight flight. If the CG is too far aft, the moment arm between it and the CP diminishes, reducing the inherent stability of the airplane beyond acceptable limits and in the extreme going negative and rendering the airplane longitudinally unstable. Generally, the less stable the aircraft, the more controllable and vice versa.

content.question: The CG of an aircraft is on the forward limit. Which of the following is a probable outcome?

options.A: There may not be enough aft stick force, resulting in a tail strike.
options.C: There may not be enough aft stick force, resulting in a nose wheel landing.
options.D: Deep stall caused by insufficient tail lift.

key_points: CENTER OF GRAVITY (CG) The total mass of the aircraft can be said to act through one point, called the Centre of Gravity (CG)
To ensure the aircraft is safe to fly, the center of gravity must fall within specified limits established by the aircraft manufacturer (between the front and the rear CG limit)
Proper CG location is crucial for maintaining the aircraft's stability and controllability
learning.explanation: CENTER OF GRAVITY (CG) The total mass of the aircraft can be said to act through one point, called the Centre of Gravity (CG). To ensure the aircraft is safe to fly, the center of gravity must fall within specified limits established by the aircraft manufacturer (between the front and the rear CG limit). Proper CG location is crucial for maintaining the aircraft's stability and controllability. Beginning from the middle of the fuselage: As the CG shifts towards the aircraft's nose, stability increases while maneuverability decreases. As the CG moves towards the tail, maneuverability improves, but stability diminishes. A more stable aircraft is less controllable and vice versa. Excessive stability leads to higher control stick forces, making it more challenging for the pilot to manage. On the other hand, excessive maneuverability results in instability and difficulty in controlling the aircraft. When the CG is at the forward limit, the aircraft's nose may become too heavy making it difficult to raise the nose during landing, leading to a higher likelihood of landing on the nose wheel rather than the main wheels.

content.question: What is a possible consequence of loading an aircraft incorrectly so that the Centre of Gravity is positioned ahead of the forward limit?

options.B: There may be insufficient forward pitch control available to keep the aircraft level.
options.C: There may be a tendency to over-pitch the aircraft during the flare just before landing.
options.D: There may be insufficient aft pitch control available to keep the aircraft level.

key_points: CG towards the forward limit makes an aircraft more stable, as a result, control forces will be higher
CG towards the aft limit decreases longitudinal static stability and reduces pitch control forces

When the Center of gravity is outside the forward limit, this gives us a pitch down moment, this pitch down moment has to be corrected by an up deflection of elevator to keep straight and level flight (by pulling the control column – control column aft)
learning.explanation: CG towards the forward limit makes an aircraft more stable, as a result, control forces will be higher. CG towards the aft limit decreases longitudinal static stability and reduces pitch control forces. When the Center of gravity is outside the forward limit, this gives us a pitch down moment, this pitch down moment has to be corrected by an up deflection of elevator to keep straight and level flight (by pulling the control column – control column aft). If the CG is located ahead of the forward limit, the aircraft's nose will be heavy, and there may not be sufficient aft pitch control available to keep the aircraft level. This can lead to difficulty in raising the nose during take-off and flare before landing, which can result in a longer take-off or landing roll, and may also make the aircraft more difficult to control in flight.

content.question: If other factors are unchanged, the fuel mileage (nautical miles per kg) is...

options.A: lower with a forward centre of gravity position
options.B: independent from the centre of gravity position
options.C: lower with an aft centre of gravity position
options.D: higher with a forward centre of gravity position

key_points: The total mass of the aircraft can be said to act through one point, called the Centre of Gravity (CG) and the total lift acts through the Centre of Pressure (CP)
The position of the CP changes with speed and as alpha changes, whilst the position of CG changes as load and fuel change
When this happens, new balancing forces and trim changes will be needed
learning.explanation: The total mass of the aircraft can be said to act through one point, called the Centre of Gravity (CG) and the total lift acts through the Centre of Pressure (CP). The position of the CP changes with speed and as alpha changes, whilst the position of CG changes as load and fuel change. When this happens, new balancing forces and trim changes will be needed. The relative positions of the CG and CP affect the longitudinal stability of the aircraft. In practice, the CG is usually forward of the CP, thus, the more forward the CG, the more stable the aircraft in pitch. Some stability in pitch is desirable, but not too much, because the extra down force on the elevator effectively adds to the aircraft weight and requires the lift to be increased to counter it. More lift means more drag created by the trim (trim drag) and more drag means higher fuel consumption. Aircraft manufacturers determine a safe range for the CG. The aft limit is usually just in front of the Centre of Pressure, but it provides less stability than that provided by the forward limit, but a smaller balancing tail moment will be required. In summary, the effects of a forward CG position are the following: Decreases the Rate of Climb and the Climb gradient Increases TORR, TODR, ASDR, thus MTOM must be decreased The stick forces required will be more Rotation will be more difficult Stall speed increases, thus ceiling decreases Makes flare more difficult during landing, thus increasing LDR and decreasing MLM Due to the increased fuel consumption, the fuel mileage (nautical miles covered per kg of fuel mass) decrease

learning.explanation: Increasing the aircraft mass also affects most of the factors associated with the CG, particularly fuel consumptiona and stalling speed. An increase in weight requires increased lift, more lift equals more drag and more drag means higher fuel consumption. Increasing mass also affects the stall speed, VS, which is roughly proportional to the square root of weight. Many speeds used in performance calculations, such as the rotate speed, VR and the safety spped, V2, are extracted through graphs and tables and are based on the stalling speed from which they differ by a standard safety margin according to the rules and regulations. content.question: What are the possible consequences when loading an aircraft incorrectly so that its CG is positioned behind the aft limit?

options.A: There may be insufficient forward pitch control available to keep the aircraft level in straight flight.
options.B: There may be insufficient aft pitch control available to keep the aircraft level in straight flight.
options.C: The aircraft will be extremely stable.
options.D: There may be an inability to flare the aircraft on landing.

key_points: The relative positions of the Centre of Gravity (CG) and Centre of Pressure (CP) affect the longitudinal stability of the aircraft
Most transport aircraft will usually have their aft CG limit just forward of the CP, because that provides to an aircraft pitch stability
If the CP is aft of the CG, the increased lift vector will tip the aircraft nose down, which is a stable result as it tends to restore the original pitch attitude
learning.explanation: The relative positions of the Centre of Gravity (CG) and Centre of Pressure (CP) affect the longitudinal stability of the aircraft. Most transport aircraft will usually have their aft CG limit just forward of the CP, because that provides to an aircraft pitch stability. If the CP is aft of the CG, the increased lift vector will tip the aircraft nose down, which is a stable result as it tends to restore the original pitch attitude. In this case, the aircraft has positive longitudinal static stability. If the CG is aft of the CP, thus positioned behind the aft limit, the increased lift will tip the aircraft nose up, leading to higher angles of attack and even more lift until the aircraft stalls. This is an unstable result, a negative longitudinal static stability, where: The control forces will be light. The aircraft will be excessively manoeuvrable, leading to a possible over rotation on take-off and a possible tail scrape and during landing over pitching may occur during the flare. Insufficient forward pitch control will be available to keep the aircraft level in straight flight.

content.question:
Given the following data for a flight, what is the usable take-off fuel mass loaded on board?
Actual Take-Off Mass: 62 800 kg
Dry Operating Mass: 34 200 kg
Crew and its baggage mass: 500 kg
Passengers and their baggage mass: 13 300 kg
Cargo mass: 5 700 kg

key_points: The takeoff mass (TOM) is the actual mass of the aeroplane at the start of the takeoff run, including everything and everyone contained within it
The dry operating mass (DOM) is the total mass of the aeroplane ready for a specific type of operation excluding usable fuel and traffic load
It is the BEM plus the variable load
learning.explanation: The takeoff mass (TOM) is the actual mass of the aeroplane at the start of the takeoff run, including everything and everyone contained within it. The dry operating mass (DOM) is the total mass of the aeroplane ready for a specific type of operation excluding usable fuel and traffic load. It is the BEM plus the variable load. The variable load includes crew and crew baggage. The usable take-off mass is calculated by deducting the dry operating mass (DOM) and the combined mass of passengers, their baggage, and cargo (traffic load) from the total take-off mass. It's important to note that the DOM already accounts for the crew and their baggage. Usable take-off fuel = Actual Take-Off Mass - DOM - Passengers and their baggage mass - cargo mass Usable take-off fuel = 62 800 kg - 34 200 kg - 13 300 kg - 5 700 kg = 9 600 kg

content.question:
Given the following information, calculate the maximum Traffic Load that can be carried:
Maximum Structural Take off Mass: 4 200 kg
Performance Limited Take off Mass: 4 200 kg
Performance Limited Landing Mass: 3 610 kg
Dry Operating Mass: 2 230 kg
Block Fuel: 865 kg
Trip Fuel: 440 kg
Taxi Fuel: 15 kg

key_points: Dry Operating Mass (DOM) is the sum of the Basic Empty Mass (BEM) and the Variable Load (crew, crew baggage, food, beverages, water etc
), excluding both usable fuel and payload
Traffic Load (TL) is the total mass of passengers, baggage, cargo (or freight), including any non-revenue load
learning.explanation: Dry Operating Mass (DOM) is the sum of the Basic Empty Mass (BEM) and the Variable Load (crew, crew baggage, food, beverages, water etc.), excluding both usable fuel and payload. Traffic Load (TL) is the total mass of passengers, baggage, cargo (or freight), including any non-revenue load. Traffic Load plus Dry Operating Mass (DOM) is equal to the aircraft's Zero Fuel Mass (ZFM). Take-off Mass (TOM) is the mass of the aeroplane at the start of the take-off run. It is equal to the ZFM plus the take-off fuel. Take-off fuel is the remaining fuel at the brake release point after having consumed the taxi fuel. Landing fuel is the remaining fuel in the tanks on landing. For this question, we will only consider the Take-off and Landing situation, subtracting from all the structural limits the Dry Operating Mass (DOM) and the fuel mass (where applicable), to find the Maximum Allowed Traffic Load that can be loaded and we will keep the lowest one: Take-off situation: Max Allowed Take off Mass - DOM - Take off fuel (Block fuel - Taxi fuel) = 4 200 kg - 2 230 kg - (865 kg - 15 kg) = 1 120 kg. Landing situation: Performance Limited Landing Mass - DOM - Landing fuel (Block - Trip -Taxi fuel) = 3 610 kg - 2 230 kg - (865 kg - 440 kg - 15 kg) = 970 kg. Therefore, the Maximum Allowed Traffic Load that can be loaded for this flight is 970 kg.

key_points: Traffic Load is the total mass of passengers, baggage, cargo (or freight), including any non-revenue load (Flight crew members are not part of the Traffic Load)

The mass values given are: Sportsmen: 105 kg Regular passengers 75 kg Baggage: 18 kg Therefore, the Traffic Load will be: 32 Sportsmen + 38 Regular Passengers + 62 Baggage items = (32 x 105 kg) + (38 x 75 kg) + (62 x 18 kg) = 7326 kg

The mass values given are: Sportsmen: 105 kg Regular passengers 75 kg Baggage: 18 kg Therefore, the Traffic Load will be: 32 Sportsmen + 38 Regular Passengers + 62 Baggage items = (32 x 105 kg) + (38 x 75 kg) + (62 x 18 kg) = 7326 kg.

content.question: The maximum mass to which an aeroplane may be loaded, prior to engine start, is…

key_points: Maximum Structural Landing Mass (MSLM): is the maximum permissible total aeroplane mass on landing in normal circumstances
It generally depends on the landing gear strength or the landing impact loads on certain parts of the wing structure
The maximum landing weight is typically designed for 10 feet per second (600 feet per minute) sink rate at touch down with no structural damage
learning.explanation: Maximum Structural Landing Mass (MSLM): is the maximum permissible total aeroplane mass on landing in normal circumstances. It generally depends on the landing gear strength or the landing impact loads on certain parts of the wing structure. The maximum landing weight is typically designed for 10 feet per second (600 feet per minute) sink rate at touch down with no structural damage. Maximum Structural Take-off Mass (MSTOM): is the maximum permissible total aeroplane mass at the start of the take-off run. Maximum Structural Taxi Mass: is the structural limitation of the mass of the aeroplane at commencement of taxi. Maximum Zero Fuel Mass (MZFM): is the maximum permissible mass of an aeroplane with no usable fuel.

If the pilot decides to refuel only the wing tanks, both inner and outer, for the forementioned purposes, then the total fuel available on-board will be: (Outer tanks x 2) + (Inner tanks x 2) = (691 kg x 2) + (5 435 kg x 2) = 1 382 kg + 10 870 kg = 12 252 kg.

content.question: Under which circumstances is zero fuel mass at its maximum?

key_points: Maximum Zero Fuel Mass (MZFM) is the maximum permissible mass of an aeroplane with no usable fuel
The MZFM is a structural limit based on the bending moments of the wing root

Due to the necessity of using the mass of fuel in the aircraft’s wing tanks to balance the internal load, there is a restriction on the amount of weight that can be placed in the fuselage before fuel must be added to the wing tanks
learning.explanation: Maximum Zero Fuel Mass (MZFM) is the maximum permissible mass of an aeroplane with no usable fuel. The MZFM is a structural limit based on the bending moments of the wing root. Due to the necessity of using the mass of fuel in the aircraft’s wing tanks to balance the internal load, there is a restriction on the amount of weight that can be placed in the fuselage before fuel must be added to the wing tanks. Exceeding the MZFM limit can result in significant structural damage to the aircraft. The greatest stress on the wing roots happens when the wing fuel tanks are empty. To prevent the wings from permanently bending upward as fuel is used, manufacturers impose a maximum zero fuel mass on the structure. Since the stress during flight is at its greatest when the wing fuel tanks are empty, MZFM is determined during approach for landing. Fuel jettison is a procedure used to quickly reduce the weight of an aircraft by releasing fuel into the atmosphere. This procedure is typically performed in emergency situations when an aircraft needs to land but is too heavy to do so safely. Note: The option 'Immediately after fuel jettison (IFJ)' is not considered the correct option, because fuel jettison does not necessarily mean getting rid of all the fuel.

content.question: Following the acceptance of the Load Sheet and the Operational Flight Plan, the Commander decides to refuel his/her aircraft with 1618 US gallons at a specific gravity of 0.8. The fuel mass loaded on board is...

key_points: Specific Gravity (SG) is a measurement of the relative density: Mass of a given volume of fluid / Mass of an equal volume of water
A relationship exists between litres and kilograms: one litre of water weighs one kilogram
A similar relationship exists between pounds or libres and imperial gallons: one IG of water weighs ten pounds or libres
learning.explanation: Specific Gravity (SG) is a measurement of the relative density: Mass of a given volume of fluid / Mass of an equal volume of water. A relationship exists between litres and kilograms: one litre of water weighs one kilogram. A similar relationship exists between pounds or libres and imperial gallons: one IG of water weighs ten pounds or libres. Based on the first relationship: Convert US gallons into litres: 1618 USG x 3.785 = 6124.13 litres. Applying the SG: 0.8 find the mass in kilos: 6124.13 kg x 0.8 = 4899.3 kg Convert kilos into libres: 4899.3 kg x 2.205 = 10802 lb

content.question:
Given the following information for an aircraft, what is its maximum Traffic Load available?
Dry Operating Mass: 3000 kg
Maximum Take-off, Landing, and Zero-fuel Mass: 5200 kg
Ramp Fuel: 650 kg
Taxi Fuel: 50 kg

key_points: Since all structural limits are identical and all of them contain at least the DOM, the most limiting factor is the MTOM, because, in addition to the DOM, it contains also the greatest amount of fuel, the Take-off fuel (in comparison with the landing fuel), which if subtracted will give the maximum available Traffic Load
Thus, the Maximum available TL will be: MTOM - DOM - Take-off fuel = MTOM - DOM - (Ramp fuel - Taxi fuel) = 5200 kg - 3000 kg - (650 kg - 50 kg) = 1600 kg

Alternatively, using a tabular format, find the maximum TL in terms of each structural limit and keep the lowest one: MTOM: 5200 kg MZFM: 5200 kg MLM: 5200 kg - DOM 3000 kg 3000 kg 3000 kg - FUEL T/O fuel: 650 - 50 = 600 kg - Landing fuel: less than 600 kg = TL 1600 kg 2200 kg More than 1600 kg Thus, the lowest TL, 1600 kg, in terms of MTOM, is the Maximum available TL
learning.explanation: Since all structural limits are identical and all of them contain at least the DOM, the most limiting factor is the MTOM, because, in addition to the DOM, it contains also the greatest amount of fuel, the Take-off fuel (in comparison with the landing fuel), which if subtracted will give the maximum available Traffic Load. Thus, the Maximum available TL will be: MTOM - DOM - Take-off fuel = MTOM - DOM - (Ramp fuel - Taxi fuel) = 5200 kg - 3000 kg - (650 kg - 50 kg) = 1600 kg. Alternatively, using a tabular format, find the maximum TL in terms of each structural limit and keep the lowest one: MTOM: 5200 kg MZFM: 5200 kg MLM: 5200 kg - DOM 3000 kg 3000 kg 3000 kg - FUEL T/O fuel: 650 - 50 = 600 kg - Landing fuel: less than 600 kg = TL 1600 kg 2200 kg More than 1600 kg Thus, the lowest TL, 1600 kg, in terms of MTOM, is the Maximum available TL.

content.question:
Given the following information, what is the Underload/Overload?
Allowed Take-off Mass: 4 300 kg
Operating Mass: 3 296 kg
Total Fuel Mass: 650 kg
Mass of the crew and their baggage: 187 kg
Traffic Load: 1 014 kg

key_points: Traffic Load (TL) is is the total mass of passengers, baggage and cargo, including any ’non-revenue’ load
Dry Operating Mass (DOM) is the total mass of the aeroplane ready for a specific type of operation excluding usable fuel and traffic load
The mass includes items such as crew and crew baggage, catering and removable passenger service equipment, potable water and lavatory chemicals, food and beverages
learning.explanation: Traffic Load (TL) is is the total mass of passengers, baggage and cargo, including any ’non-revenue’ load. Dry Operating Mass (DOM) is the total mass of the aeroplane ready for a specific type of operation excluding usable fuel and traffic load. The mass includes items such as crew and crew baggage, catering and removable passenger service equipment, potable water and lavatory chemicals, food and beverages. Operating Mass (OM) is the DOM plus fuel, but without traffic load. For this question we will only consider the take-off situation (ignoring the landing and the zero-fuel situation, since the given data do not permit so) subtracting from the Allowed Take-off mass structural limit, the OM and the Traffic load to figure out if the aircraft is overloaded or underloaded: Allowed TOM - OM - Traffic Load = 4 300 kg - 3 296 kg - 1 014 kg = - 10 kg. The "-" sign indicates that it is overloaded by 10 kg. NOTE: Be careful to avoid any double mass calculations, due to the fact that some masses are already included in other masses, e.g. fuel mass is included in OM, crew and crew baggage mass is included in DOM, DOM is included in OM and so on.

content.question: What is the minimum width of a clearway?

key_points: The clearway is described in EU-OPS, as a defined rectangular area on the ground or water under the control of the appropriate authority, selected or prepared as a suitable area over which an aeroplane may take a portion of its initial climb to a specified height
The clearway may be load bearing or not
The clearway is expressed in terms of a clearway plane with a minimum width of 500 feet (or 152 metres), extending from the end of the runway with an upward slope not exceeding 1
learning.explanation: The clearway is described in EU-OPS, as a defined rectangular area on the ground or water under the control of the appropriate authority, selected or prepared as a suitable area over which an aeroplane may take a portion of its initial climb to a specified height. The clearway may be load bearing or not. The clearway is expressed in terms of a clearway plane with a minimum width of 500 feet (or 152 metres), extending from the end of the runway with an upward slope not exceeding 1.25%, above which no object or terrain protrudes. However, threshold lights may protrude above the plane, if their height above the end of the runway is 0.66 metres (or 26 inches) or less and if they are located to each side of the runway. Also, the clearway may not be greater than 50% of the TORA and should extend at least 75 metres either side of the centre line. The TORA (Take-Off Run Available) plus the clearway make the TODA (Take-Off Distance Available).

content.question:
Refer to figure.
Determine the Landing Mass, given:
Basic Empty Mass: 3210 lb
Pilot and front passenger: 380 lb
Passengers (centre seats): 330 lb
Baggage zone 1: 100 lb
Baggage zone 4: 100 lb
Fuel loading: 85 US gal

Fuel density: 6 lb/US gal

key_points: The total aircraft mass at landing (landing mass) is the take-off mass reduced by all fuel used during the particular flight
In other words, LM is the zero fuel mass (ZFM) plus all fuel that should still be onboard
In this case, the fuel at landing will equal to the fuel loading minus fuel allowance for start, taxi and run up, minus estimated fuel burn-off
learning.explanation: The total aircraft mass at landing (landing mass) is the take-off mass reduced by all fuel used during the particular flight. In other words, LM is the zero fuel mass (ZFM) plus all fuel that should still be onboard. In this case, the fuel at landing will equal to the fuel loading minus fuel allowance for start, taxi and run up, minus estimated fuel burn-off. Fuel loading (lb) = 85 US Gal x 6 lb/US gal = 510 lb Fuel allowance for start, taxi and run up (lb) = 4 US gal x 6 lb/US gal = 24 lb Estimated fuel burn-off (lb) = 60 US gal x 6 lb/US gal = 360 lb Fuel at landing (lb) = 510 lb - 24 lb - 360 lb = 126 lb Landing Mass (LM) = BEM + Pilot and front passenger + Passengers + Baggage Zone 1 + Baggage Zone 4 + Fuel at landing Landing Mass (LM) = 3 210 lb + 380 lb + 330 lb + 100 lb + 100 lb + 126 lb = 4 246 lb

content.question: The Variable Load of an aircraft consists of the following:

options.A: The mass of all persons and items of load, including fuel and other consumable fluids.
options.B: The mass of all passengers, crew and their baggage, less fuel and consumable fluids.
options.C: The mass of crew, their baggage, plus removable units of equipment.

learning.explanation: The Variable Load (VL) consists of mass of the crew, their baggage and any removable equipment that is required for that flight, for instance catering and passenger service equipment, food and beverages, potable water and lavatory chemicals. The Variable Load is often referred to as "Operational Items". The Operator is responsible for determining the VL, which is calculated either with actual crew masses and their baggage or with standard masses. EU-OPS quotes 85 kg for flight crew and 75 kg for cabin crew, including their hand baggage, but the Operator may use other standard masses acceptable to the Authority. The Operator adds the Variable Load to the Basic Empty Mass to establish the Dry Operating Mass (BEM + VL = DOM).

According to the flight Manual, the Maximum Structural Mass of your aircraft is 3720 lb, which may be increased by 20 lb for taxiing.
It is a hot day and the performance charts restrict the Maximum All up Mass (MAUM) to 3640 lb. What is the value of the regulated Take-Off mass (RTOM)?

key_points: Regulated Take-off Mass (RTOM) is the maximum permitted take-off mass of the aeroplane at the start of the take-off run, derived by complying with all the requirements of the weight and performance regulations appropriate to the flight
The Regulated Take-off Mass is the most restrictive of the Field-Length-Limited TOM, Climb-Limited TOM, Tyre Speed-Limited TOM and the Maximum Structural TOM
All these limits are taken into account by both Electronic Flight Bag (EFB) take-off and landing calculations and RTOM tables
learning.explanation: Regulated Take-off Mass (RTOM) is the maximum permitted take-off mass of the aeroplane at the start of the take-off run, derived by complying with all the requirements of the weight and performance regulations appropriate to the flight. The Regulated Take-off Mass is the most restrictive of the Field-Length-Limited TOM, Climb-Limited TOM, Tyre Speed-Limited TOM and the Maximum Structural TOM. All these limits are taken into account by both Electronic Flight Bag (EFB) take-off and landing calculations and RTOM tables. For this question the Maximum All up Mass is reduced because of the increased temperature, which affects negatively the aircraft's performance. The Regulated Take-Off Mass is the lower of the two maximum structural limits, 3640 lb.

Before departure for a flight, the load controller presents to you cargo documents for boxes containing spare parts. These boxes have a total mass of 4500 kg. If you accept all the boxes, given the following information, what will be the Underload/Overload?

Maximum Zero Fuel Mass: 62731 kg
Operating Mass: 58799 kg

Take-off fuel: 16299 kg

key_points: Traffic Load (TL) is the total mass of passengers, baggage and cargo, including any ’non-revenue’ load
Dry Operating Mass (DOM) is the total mass of the aeroplane ready for a specific type of operation excluding usable fuel and traffic load
The mass includes items such as crew and crew baggage, catering and removable passenger service equipment, potable water and lavatory chemicals, food and beverages
learning.explanation: Traffic Load (TL) is the total mass of passengers, baggage and cargo, including any ’non-revenue’ load. Dry Operating Mass (DOM) is the total mass of the aeroplane ready for a specific type of operation excluding usable fuel and traffic load. The mass includes items such as crew and crew baggage, catering and removable passenger service equipment, potable water and lavatory chemicals, food and beverages. Operating Mass (OM) is the DOM plus fuel, but without traffic load. Zero Fuel Mass (ZFM) is the total mass of the aeroplane less the usable fuel (DOM + Traffic Load or TOM - Fuel). For this question we will only consider the Zero-fuel and Take-off situations (ignoring the landing situation, since the given data do not permit so), subtracting from the Allowed Take-off Mass (ATOM) and the Maximum Zero-Fuel Mass (MZFM) structural limits the Actual ZFM and the fuel mass (where applicable), to figure out if the aircraft is overloaded or underloaded: ATOM - Actual ZFM - TOF = 76720 kg - 55063 kg - 16299 kg = 5358 kg underloaded. MZFM - Actual ZFM = 62731 kg - 55063 kg = 7668 kg underload. We will select the lowest of the two numbers and then apply the additional cargo of 4500 kg we will check out if we are finally underloaded or overloaded and by how much: 5358 kg - 4500 kg = 858 kg underloaded. NOTE: Be careful to avoid any double mass calculations, due to the fact that some masses are already included in other masses, e.g. fuel mass is included in OM, crew and crew baggage mass is included in DOM, DOM is included in OM and so on.

The mass includes items such as crew and crew baggage, catering and removable passenger service equipment, potable water and lavatory chemicals, food and beverages. Block fuel or Ramp fuel is the total fuel loaded into the aeroplane (Taxi fuel plus Take-off fuel). For this question we will only consider the Take-off situation (ignoring the landing situation, since the given data do not permit so), subtracting from the Allowed Take-off Mass (ATOM) structural limit the Dry Operating Mass (DOM) and the Traffic Load (TL) to find the Maximum Take-off fuel that can be loaded: Maximum T/O fuel = ATOM - DOM - TL + Taxi fuel= 8100 kg - 4737 kg - 1459 kg = 1904 kg. Thus, the Maximum Block fuel is: Maximum T/O fuel + Taxi fuel = 1904 kg + 35 kg = 1939 kg.

learning.explanation: Dry Operating Mass (DOM) is the sum of the Basic Empty Mass (BEM) and the Variable Load (crew, crew baggage, food, beverages, water etc.), excluding both usable fuel and payload. Traffic Load (TL) is the total mass of passengers, baggage, cargo (or freight), including any non-revenue load. Traffic Load plus Dry Operating Mass (DOM) is equal to the aircraft's Zero Fuel Mass (ZFM). Take-off Mass (TOM) is the mass of the aeroplane at the start of the take-off run. It is equal to the ZFM plus the take-off fuel. Take-off fuel is the remaining fuel at the brake release point after having consumed the taxi fuel. For this question, we will only consider the Take-off and Zero-fuel situation, subtracting from all the structural limits the Dry Operating Mass (DOM) and the fuel mass (where applicable), to find the Maximum Allowed Traffic Load that can be loaded and we will keep the lowest one: Take-off situation: Maximum Take off Mass - DOM - Take off fuel = 71 204 kg - 40 195 kg - (13 800 kg - 215 kg) = 17 424 kg. content.question: For mass and balance purposes 650 lbs of Jet A-1 fuel needs to be drained before take-off. What is the volume of the drained fuel, if its specific gravity is 0.80?

key_points: A relationship exists between litres and kilograms: 1 litre of water weighs, 1 kilogram
A similar relationship exists between pounds and imperial gallons (IG): 1 IG of water, weighs 10 pounds

To convert from volumes to mass or mass to volumes, you need the Specific Gravity of the fuel: The Specific Gravity (SG) shows the relationship between litres and kilograms or between pounds and imperial gallons
learning.explanation: A relationship exists between litres and kilograms: 1 litre of water weighs, 1 kilogram. A similar relationship exists between pounds and imperial gallons (IG): 1 IG of water, weighs 10 pounds. To convert from volumes to mass or mass to volumes, you need the Specific Gravity of the fuel: The Specific Gravity (SG) shows the relationship between litres and kilograms or between pounds and imperial gallons. Specific Gravity 0.80 means that a volume of fuel weighs 80% of the equivalent volume of water. For this question, 650 lb of fuel has a fuel volume of: 650 lb / 10 / 0.80 = 81 IG. And, since 1 IG = 1.2 USG, then: 81 IG = 81 x 1.2 = 97 USG. NOTES: 1. Fuel volume is measured in: Imperial Gallons (IG), US Gallons (USG) or litres (l or lt). 2. Fuel mass is measured in:, tonnes (t or ton), kilograms (kg) or pounds (lb).

(i) Pounds (lb) to Kilograms (kg) => lb × 0.454 2470 lb x 0.454 = 1121 kg (ii) Conversion between Fuel volume and mass: Fuel Mass in kg / Specific Gravity (density) = Fuel Volume in L 1121 kg / 0.82 = 1367 l 2. content.question: An aircraft's Operating Mass is equal to the...

options.B: TOM - Traffic Load - Take-Off Fuel - Variable Load.

key_points: This question, like many others, tests knowledge of both various mass definitions and also their relationship to each other
An ability to sketch and understand a diagram, is considered an essential skill in this subject
CAP 696 defines Operating Mass (OM) as the DOM plus fuel but without traffic load
learning.explanation: This question, like many others, tests knowledge of both various mass definitions and also their relationship to each other. An ability to sketch and understand a diagram, is considered an essential skill in this subject. CAP 696 defines Operating Mass (OM) as the DOM plus fuel but without traffic load. Taking this definition further, the Basic Empty Mass (BEM) plus the Variable Load (VL) equal the Dry Operating Mass (DOM). To the DOM, if fuel is added then we arrive at the Operating Mass (OM). This fuel is normally take-off fuel prior to flight and usable fuel after take-off. More detailed definitions of both BEM and DOM from CAP 696 are found here: Basic Empty Mass (Basic Mass) is the mass of an aeroplane plus standard items such as: unusable fuel and other unusable fluids; lubricating oil in engine and auxiliary units; fire extinguishers; pyrotechnics; emergency oxygen equipment; supplementary electronic equipment. Dry Operating Mass (DOM) is the total mass of the aeroplane ready for a specific type of operation excluding usable fuel and traffic load. The mass includes items such as: Crew and crew baggage. Catering and removable passenger service equipment. Potable water and lavatory chemicals. Food and beverages Note: The term 'variable load' is not directly defined in CAP 696 but the details are listed in the definition of DOM, as above.

content.question: In a turn flight, which scenario will cause the most bending moment at the wing root?

key_points: Maximum Zero Fuel Mass (MZFM) is the maximum permissible mass of an aeroplane with no usable fuel
The MZFM is a structural limit based on the bending moments of the wing root
All extra weight above the MZFM must comprise fuel only
learning.explanation: Maximum Zero Fuel Mass (MZFM) is the maximum permissible mass of an aeroplane with no usable fuel. The MZFM is a structural limit based on the bending moments of the wing root. All extra weight above the MZFM must comprise fuel only. The added fuel, which is invariably carried in the wing increases its stiffness and reduces its bending and torsion (twisting). Fuel being stored in the wings is a useful feature, as the weight of the fuel counteracts the lift generated and gives relief to the roots of the cantilever wing. However, with no fuel, the wings are light, and the fuselage is heavy, which causes a large moment at the root of the wing. Therefore, the maximum zero-fuel weight implies a protection to the wing root against being overstressed. As long as it is not exceeded, lack of large amounts of fuel in the wings will not cause failure at the wing roots because of bending.
